question: Question_01_(d)
statement:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show
your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions
are of equal difficulty.

Fill in the blanks with right, left, or midpoint; an interval; and a
value of $n$.

$\sum_{k=0}^{3}f(1.5 + k)\cdot 1$ is a \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Riemann sum
for $\displaystyle f$ on the interval {[}\_\_\_\_ , \_\_\_\_{]} with
$\displaystyle n =$ \_\_\_\_\_\_.
sols:
There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but
one of three possible interpretations:

This is a left Riemann sum from 1.5 to 5.5 with $n=4$ rectangles.

If we look at our left endpoint formula in the hint, we realize that

\begin{align*}
a&=1.5\\
n&=4\\
\Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{align*}

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.5.

There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but
one of three possible interpretations:

This is a midpoint Riemann sum from 1 to 5 with $n=4$ rectangles.

We can recognize this by writing

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=0}^3f(1.5+k)=\sum_{k=0}^3f(1+(k+1/2))\end{align*}

which is in the form of our midpoint formula in the hint if we take

\begin{align*}
a&=1\\
n&=4\\
\Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{align*}

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.

There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but
one of three possible interpretations:

This is a right endpoint Riemann sum from 0.5 to 4.5 with $n=4$
rectangles.

We can recognize this by writing

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=0}^3f(1.5+k)=\sum_{k=0}^3f(0.5+(k+1))\end{align*}

which is in the form of our right endpoint formula in the hint if we
take

\begin{align*}
a&=0.5\\
n&=4\\
\Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{align*}

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=4.5.
hints:
The left Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

The midpoint Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1/2)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

The right Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^{n} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{align*}

or

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$
